entities.title: Louis II, Elector of Brandenburg
entities.description: Louis the Roman was the eldest son of Emperor Louis IV the Bavarian by his second wife, Margaret II, Countess of Hainault, and a member of the House of Wittelsbach. Louis was Duke of Bavaria as Louis VI (1347–1365) and Margrave of Brandenburg (1351–1365) as Louis II. As of 1356, he also served as Prince-elector of Brandenburg.

heading: Deaths
txt: Konstantin Dejanović/Constantine Dragaš, Serbian ruler (b. 1355)

entities.title: Konstantin Dejanović
entities.description: Konstantin (Kostadin) Dejanović was a Serbian magnate that ruled a large province in eastern Macedonia under Ottoman suzerainty, during the fall of the Serbian Empire. He succeeded his older brother Jovan Dragaš, who had been an Ottoman vassal since the Battle of Maritsa (1371) which had devastated part of the Serbian nobility. The brothers had their own government and minted coins according to th

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas de Ros, 9th Baron de Ros, English politician (b. 1427)

entities.title: Thomas de Ros, 9th Baron de Ros
entities.description: Thomas Ros or Roos, 9th Baron Ros of Helmsley was a follower of the House of Lancaster during the Wars of the Roses.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sandro Botticelli, Italian painter (b. 1445)

entities.title: Sandro Botticelli
entities.description: Alessandro di Mariano di Vanni Filipepi, known as Sandro Botticelli, was an Italian painter of the Early Renaissance. Botticelli's posthumous reputation suffered until the late 19th century, when he was rediscovered by the Pre-Raphaelites who stimulated a reappraisal of his work. Since then, his paintings have been seen to represent the linear grace of Early Renaissance painting.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Stafford, 3rd Duke of Buckingham, Welsh politician, Lord High Constable of England (b. 1478)

entities.title: Edward Stafford, 3rd Duke of Buckingham
entities.description: Edward Stafford, 3rd Duke of Buckingham was an English nobleman. He was the son of Henry Stafford, 2nd Duke of Buckingham, and Katherine Woodville, and nephew of Elizabeth Woodville and King Edward IV. Thus Edward Stafford was a first cousin once removed of King Henry VIII. He was convicted of treason and executed on 17 May 1521.

entities.title: Lord High Constable of England
entities.description: The Lord High Constable of England is the seventh of the Great Officers of State, ranking beneath the Lord Great Chamberlain and above the Earl Marshal. His office is now called out of abeyance only for coronations. The Lord High Constable was originally the commander of the royal armies and the Master of the Horse. He was also, in conjunction with the Earl Marshal, president of the court of chiva

heading: Deaths
txt: George Boleyn, 2nd Viscount Rochford, English courtier and diplomat, Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports (b. 1504)

entities.title: George Boleyn, 2nd Viscount Rochford
entities.description: George Boleyn, Viscount Rochford was an English courtier and nobleman who played a prominent role in the politics of the early 1530s, and was the brother of Queen Anne Boleyn, from 1533 the second wife of King Henry VIII and thus the maternal uncle of Queen Elizabeth I. Following his father's promotion in the peerage in 1529 to Earl of Wiltshire and Earl of Ormond, he adopted his father's junior t

entities.title: Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports
entities.description: The Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports is a ceremonial official in the United Kingdom. The post dates from at least the 12th century, when the title was Keeper of the Coast, but may be older. The Lord Warden was originally in charge of the Cinque Ports, a group of five port towns on the southeast coast of England that was formed to collectively supply ships for The Crown in the absence at the time of

heading: Deaths
txt: William Brereton, English courtier (b. 1487)

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Norris, English courtier (b. 1482)

heading: Deaths
txt: Philipp von Hutten, German explorer (b. 1511)

entities.title: Philipp von Hutten
entities.description: Philipp von Hutten was a German adventurer, and an early European explorer of Venezuela. He is a significant figure in the history of Klein-Venedig, the concession of Venezuela Province to the Welser banking family by Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain.

heading: Deaths
txt: Shin Saimdang, South Korean poet and calligraphist (b. 1504)

entities.title: Shin Saimdang
entities.description: Shin Saimdang was a Korean artist, writer, calligraphist, and poet. She was born in Gangwondo Gangneung-bu Jukheon-li Bukpyeong-chon. Her birth home, Ojukheon, which is also her mother's side home, is well-preserved to this day. She was the mother of the Korean Confucian scholar Yi I. Often held up as a model of Confucian ideals, her respectful nickname was Eojin Eomeoni. Her real name was Shin In

heading: Deaths
txt: Francisco de Sá de Miranda, Portuguese poet (b. 1485)

entities.title: Francisco de Sá de Miranda
entities.description: Francisco de Sá de Miranda was a Portuguese poet of the Renaissance.

heading: Deaths
txt: Matthew Parker, English archbishop and academic (b. 1504)

entities.title: Matthew Parker
entities.description: Matthew Parker was an English bishop. He was the Archbishop of Canterbury in the Church of England from 1559 until his death in 1575. He was also an influential theologian and arguably the co-founder of a distinctive tradition of Anglican theological thought.

heading: Deaths
txt: False Dmitriy I, pretender to the Russian throne (b. 1582)

entities.title: False Dmitriy I
entities.description: False Dmitry I reigned as the Tsar of Russia from 10 June 1605 until his death on 17 May 1606 under the name of Dmitry Ivanovich. According to historian Chester S.L. Dunning, Dmitry was "the only Tsar ever raised to the throne by means of a military campaign and popular uprisings".

heading: Deaths
txt: Anna d'Este, French princess (b. 1531)

entities.title: Anna d'Este
entities.description: Anna d'Este was an important princess with considerable influence at the court of France and a central figure in the French Wars of Religion. In her first marriage she was Duchess of Aumale, then of Guise, in her second marriage Duchess of Nemours and Genevois.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joan Pau Pujol, Catalan organist and composer (b. 1570)

entities.title: Joan Pau Pujol
entities.description: Joan Pau Pujol was a Catalan and Spanish composer and organist of the late Renaissance and early Baroque. While best known for his sacred music, he also wrote popular secular music.

heading: Deaths
txt: Giovanni Picchi, Italian organist and composer (b. 1571)

entities.title: Giovanni Picchi
entities.description: Giovanni Picchi was an Italian composer, organist, lutenist, and harpsichordist of the early Baroque era. He was a late follower of the Venetian School, and was influential in the development and differentiation of instrumental forms which were just beginning to appear, such as the sonata and the ensemble canzona; in addition he was the only Venetian of his time to write dance music for harpsichor

heading: Deaths
txt: Catherine I of Russia (b. 1684)

entities.title: Catherine I of Russia
entities.description: Catherine I was the second wife and Empress consort of Peter the Great, and Empress regnant of Russia from 1725 until her death in 1727.

heading: Deaths
txt: Samuel Clarke, English clergyman and philosopher (b. 1675)

entities.title: Samuel Clarke
entities.description: Samuel Clarke was an English philosopher and Anglican cleric. He is considered the major British figure in philosophy between John Locke and George Berkeley.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexis Clairaut, French mathematician, astronomer, and geophysicist (b. 1713)

entities.title: Alexis Clairaut
entities.description: Alexis Claude Clairaut was a French mathematician, astronomer, and geophysicist. He was a prominent Newtonian whose work helped to establish the validity of the principles and results that Sir Isaac Newton had outlined in the Principia of 1687. Clairaut was one of the key figures in the expedition to Lapland that helped to confirm Newton's theory for the figure of the Earth. In that context, Clair

heading: Deaths
txt: Michel-Jean Sedaine, French playwright and composer (b. 1719)

entities.title: Michel-Jean Sedaine
entities.description: Michel-Jean Sedaine was a French dramatist and librettist, especially noted for his librettos for opéras comiques, in which he took an important and influential role in the advancement of the genre from the period of Charles-Simon Favart to the beginning of the Revolution.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Heberden, English physician and scholar (b. 1710)

entities.title: William Heberden
entities.description: Dr William Heberden FRS was an English physician.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Gunby, American general (b. 1745)

entities.title: John Gunby
entities.description: John Gunby was an American planter and soldier from Somerset County, Maryland who is considered by many to be "one of the most gallant officers of the Maryland Line under Gen. Smallwood". He entered service volunteering as a minuteman in 1775 and fought for the American cause until the end earning praise as probably the most brilliant soldier whom Maryland contributed to the War of Independence. G

heading: Deaths
txt: Leopold Auenbrugger, Austrian physician (b. 1722)

entities.title: Leopold Auenbrugger
entities.description: Josef Leopold Auenbrugger or Avenbrugger, also known as Leopold von Auenbrugger, was an Austrian physician who invented percussion as a diagnostic technique. On the strength of this discovery, he is considered one of the founders of modern medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Armand-Emmanuel de Vignerot du Plessis, Duc de Richelieu, French general and politician, 2nd Prime Minister of France (b. 1766)

entities.title: Armand-Emmanuel de Vignerot du Plessis, Duc de Richelieu
entities.description: Armand-Emmanuel Sophie Septimanie de Vignerot du Plessis, 5th Duke of Richelieu and Fronsac, was a prominent French statesman during the Bourbon Restoration. He was known by the courtesy title of Count of Chinon until 1788, then Duke of Fronsac until 1791, when he succeeded his father as Duke of Richelieu.

entities.title: Prime Minister of France
entities.description: The prime minister of the French Republic, sometimes shortened to premier, is the head of government of France. During the Third and Fourth Republics, the head of government was formally called president of the Council of Ministers, generally shortened to president of the Council. However, the post was usually called "prime minister" or "premier" in non-French sources. The prime minister is the ho

heading: Deaths
txt: John Jay, American politician and diplomat, 1st Chief Justice of the United States (b. 1745)

entities.title: John Jay
entities.description: John Jay was an American statesman, patriot, diplomat, Founding Father, abolitionist, negotiator, and signatory of the Treaty of Paris of 1783. He served as the second Governor of New York and the first Chief Justice of the United States (1789–1795). He directed U.S. foreign policy for much of the 1780s and was an important leader of the Federalist Party after the ratification of the United States

entities.title: Chief Justice of the United States
entities.description: The chief justice of the United States is the chief judge of the Supreme Court of the United States and the highest-ranking officer of the U.S. federal judiciary. Article II, Section 2, Clause 2 of the U.S. Constitution grants plenary power to the president of the United States to nominate, and with the advice and consent of the United States Senate, appoint "Judges of the supreme Court", who serv

heading: Deaths
txt: René Caillié, French explorer and author (b. 1799)

entities.title: René Caillié
entities.description: Auguste René Caillié was a French explorer and the first European to return alive from the town of Timbuktu. Caillié had been preceded at Timbuktu by a British officer, Major Gordon Laing, who was murdered in September 1826 on leaving the city. Caillié was therefore the first to return alive.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord, French bishop and politician, Prime Minister of France (b. 1754)

entities.title: Prime Minister of France
entities.description: The prime minister of the French Republic, sometimes shortened to premier, is the head of government of France. During the Third and Fourth Republics, the head of government was formally called president of the Council of Ministers, generally shortened to president of the Council. However, the post was usually called "prime minister" or "premier" in non-French sources. The prime minister is the ho

heading: Deaths
txt: Archibald Alison, Scottish priest and author (b. 1757)

entities.title: Archibald Alison (author)
entities.description: Archibald Alison FRS FRSE was a Scottish episcopalian priest and essayist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kondō Isami, Japanese commander (b. 1834)

entities.title: Kondō Isami
entities.description: Kondō Isami  was a Japanese swordsman and official of the late Edo period. He was the fourth generation master of Tennen Rishin-ryū and was famed for his role as commander of the Shinsengumi.

heading: Deaths
txt: John C. Breckinridge, American lawyer and politician, 14th Vice President of the United States, Confederate States general (b. 1821)

entities.title: John C. Breckinridge
entities.description: John Cabell Breckinridge was an American lawyer, politician, and soldier. He represented Kentucky in both houses of Congress and became the 14th and youngest-ever Vice President of the United States. Serving from 1857 to 1861, he took office at the age of 36. He was a member of the Democratic Party, and served in the U.S. Senate during the outbreak of the American Civil War, but was expelled after

entities.title: Vice President of the United States
entities.description: The vice president of the United States (VPOTUS) is the second-highest officer in the executive branch of the U.S. federal government, after the president of the United States, and ranks first in the presidential line of succession. The vice president is also an officer in the legislative branch, as the president of the Senate. In this capacity, the vice president is empowered to preside over Sena

entities.title: Confederate States
entities.description: The Confederate States of America (CSA), commonly referred to as the Confederate States or the Confederacy, was an unrecognized breakaway state in existence from February 8, 1861, to May 9, 1865, that fought against the United States of America during the American Civil War. The eleven states that seceded from the Union and formed the main part of the CSA were South Carolina, Mississippi, Florida,

heading: Deaths
txt: Asa Packer, American businessman, founded Lehigh University (b. 1805)

entities.title: Asa Packer
entities.description: Asa Packer was an American businessman who pioneered railroad construction, was active in Pennsylvania politics, and founded Lehigh University. He was a conservative and religious man who reflected the image of the typical Connecticut Yankee. He served two terms in the United States House of Representatives (1853–1857).

entities.title: Lehigh University
entities.description: Lehigh University (LU) is a private research university in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania. It was established in 1865 by businessman Asa Packer. Its undergraduate programs have been coeducational since the 1971–72 academic year. As of 2019, the university had 5,047 undergraduate students and 1,802 graduate students.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ziya Pasha, Greek author and translator (b. 1826)

entities.title: Ziya Pasha
entities.description: Ziya Pasha, the pseudonym of Abdul Hamid Ziyaeddin, was an Ottoman writer, translator and administrator. He was, along with İbrahim Şinasi and Namık Kemal, one of the most important authors during the Tanzimat period of the Ottoman Empire.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Deere, American blacksmith and businessman, founded the Deere & Company (b. 1804)

entities.title: John Deere (inventor)
entities.description: John Deere was an American blacksmith and manufacturer who founded Deere & Company, one of the largest and leading agricultural and construction equipment manufacturers in the world. Born in Rutland, Vermont, Deere moved to Illinois and invented the first commercially successful steel plow in 1837.

entities.title: Deere & Company
entities.description: John Deere is the brand name of Deere & Company, an American corporation that manufactures agricultural, construction, and forestry machinery, diesel engines, drivetrains used in heavy equipment, and lawn care equipment. In 2019, it was listed as 87th in the Fortune 500 America's ranking and was ranked 329th in the global ranking. The company also provides financial services and other related acti

heading: Deaths
txt: Giacomo Zanella, Italian priest and poet (b. 1820)

entities.title: Giacomo Zanella
entities.description: Giacomo Zanella was an Italian poet.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederick August Otto Schwarz, German-American businessman, founded FAO Schwarz (b. 1836)

entities.title: Frederick August Otto Schwarz
entities.description: Frederick August Otto Schwarz was a German-born American toy retailer known for founding FAO Schwarz.

entities.title: FAO Schwarz
entities.description: FAO Schwarz is an American toy brand and store. The company is known for its high-end toys, life-sized stuffed animals, interactive experiences, brand integrations, and games.

heading: Deaths
txt: Boris Borisovich Golitsyn, Russian physicist and seismologist (b. 1862)

entities.title: Boris Borisovich Golitsyn
entities.description: Prince Boris Borisovich Golitsyn was a prominent Russian physicist who invented the first electromagnetic seismograph in 1906. He was one of the founders of modern Seismology. In 1911 he was chosen to be the president of the International Seismology Association.

heading: Deaths
txt: Clara Ayres, American nurse (b. 1880)

entities.title: Clara Ayres
entities.description: Clara Ayres (1880–1917) was an American nurse, who joined the United States Army during the First World War. Ayres and Helen Burnett Wood were the first two women to be killed while serving in the United States military, following an explosion on USS Mongolia on May 17, 1917.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Brooke, Rajah of Sarawak (b. 1829)

heading: Deaths
txt: Guido von List, Austrian-German journalist, author, and poet (b. 1848)

entities.title: Guido von List
entities.description: Guido Karl Anton List, better known as Guido von List, was an Austrian occultist, journalist, playwright, and novelist. He expounded a modern Pagan new religious movement known as Wotanism, which he claimed was the revival of the religion of the ancient German race, and which included an inner set of Ariosophical teachings that he termed Armanism.

heading: Deaths
txt: Karl Mantzius, Danish actor and director (b. 1860)

entities.title: Karl Mantzius
entities.description: Karl Mantzius was a Danish actor, stage and film director, theatre scholar, and operatic baritone.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dorothy Levitt, English racing driver and journalist (b. 1882)

entities.title: Dorothy Levitt
entities.description: Dorothy Elizabeth Levitt, was the first British woman racing driver, holder of the world's first water speed record, the women's world land speed record holder, and an author. She was a pioneer of female independence and female motoring, and taught Queen Alexandra and the Royal Princesses how to drive. In 1905 she established the record for the longest drive achieved by a lady driver by driving a

heading: Deaths
txt: Harold Geiger, American pilot and lieutenant (b. 1884)

entities.title: Harold Geiger
entities.description: Major Harold Geiger was US military aviator number 6, who was killed in an airplane crash in 1927. He was also a balloonist. Spokane International Airport is designated with the International Air Transport Association airport code GEG in his memory.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cass Gilbert, American architect (b. 1859)

entities.title: Cass Gilbert
entities.description: Cass Gilbert was a prominent American architect. An early proponent of skyscrapers, his works include the Woolworth Building, the United States Supreme Court building, the state capitols of Minnesota, Arkansas and West Virginia; and the Saint Louis Art Museum and Public Library. His public buildings in the Beaux Arts style reflect the optimistic American sense that the nation was heir to Greek dem

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Dukas, French composer, critic, and educator (b. 1865)

entities.title: Paul Dukas
entities.description: Paul Abraham Dukas was a French composer, critic, scholar and teacher. A studious man of retiring personality, he was intensely self-critical, having abandoned and destroyed many of his compositions. His best-known work is the orchestral piece The Sorcerer's Apprentice, the fame of which has eclipsed that of his other surviving works. Among these are the opera Ariane et Barbe-bleue, his Symphony i

heading: Deaths
txt: Panagis Tsaldaris, Greek lawyer and politician, 124th Prime Minister of Greece (b. 1868)

entities.title: Panagis Tsaldaris
entities.description: Panagis Tsaldaris was a Greek politician and the 48th Prime Minister of Greece. He was a revered conservative politician and leader for many years (1922–1936) of the conservative People's Party in the period before World War II. He was the husband of Lina Tsaldari, a Greek suffragist, member of Parliament, and the Minister for Social Welfare.

entities.title: List of Prime Ministers of Greece
entities.description: This is a list of the heads of government of the modern Greek state, from its establishment during the Greek Revolution to the present day. Although various official and semi-official appellations were used during the early decades of independent statehood, the title of prime minister has been the formal designation of the office at least since 1843. On dates, Greece officially adopted the Gregori

heading: Deaths
txt: Jakob Ehrlich, Czech-Austrian academic and politician (b. 1877)

entities.title: Jakob Ehrlich
entities.description: Jakob Ehrlich was an early Zionist and leader of the Jewish Community in Vienna, Austria. Ehrlich represented the city's 180,000 Jewish citizens in the city government before World War II, and was among those deported in the "Prominententransport" to the Nazi concentration camp at Dachau, soon after the German army entered Vienna in March 1938. He died in Dachau a few weeks later, from beatings.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johanna Elberskirchen, German author and activist (b. 1864)

entities.title: Johanna Elberskirchen
entities.description: Johanna Elberskirchen was a feminist writer and activist for the rights of women, gays and lesbians as well as blue-collar workers. She published books on women's sexuality and health among other topics. Her last known public appearance was in 1930 in Vienna, where she gave a talk at a conference organised by the World League for Sexual Reform. She was open about her own homosexuality which made h

heading: Deaths
txt: George Forbes, New Zealand farmer and politician, 22nd Prime Minister of New Zealand (b. 1869)

entities.title: George Forbes (New Zealand politician)
entities.description: George William Forbes was a New Zealand politician who served as the 22nd Prime Minister of New Zealand from 28 May 1930 to 6 December 1935.

entities.title: Prime Minister of New Zealand
entities.description: The prime minister of New Zealand is the head of government of New Zealand. The incumbent prime minister, Jacinda Ardern, leader of the New Zealand Labour Party, took office on 26 October 2017.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Birdwood, Anglo-Indian field marshal (b. 1865)

entities.title: William Birdwood
entities.description: Field Marshal William Riddell Birdwood, 1st Baron Birdwood, was a British Army officer. He saw active service in the Second Boer War on the staff of Lord Kitchener. He saw action again in the First World War as Commander of the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps during the Gallipoli Campaign in 1915, leading the landings on the peninsula and then the evacuation later in the year, before becomin

heading: Deaths
txt: Jules Supervielle, Uruguayan-French poet and author (b. 1884)

entities.title: Jules Supervielle
entities.description: Jules Supervielle was a Franco-Uruguayan poet and writer born in Montevideo. He was nominated for the Nobel Prize in Literature three times.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Wilce, American football player, coach, and physician (b. 1888)

entities.title: John Wilce
entities.description: John Woodworth Wilce was an American football player and coach, physician, and university professor. He served as the head football coach at Ohio State University from 1913 to 1928, compiling a record of 78–33–9. Wilce is best known for coaching the great Chic Harley and leading Ohio State to their first win over archrival Michigan in 1919. He was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame as

heading: Deaths
txt: Nandor Fodor, Hungarian-American psychologist and parapsychologist (b. 1895)

entities.title: Nandor Fodor
entities.description: Nandor Fodor was a British and American parapsychologist, psychoanalyst, author and journalist of Hungarian origin.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ernest Nash, German-American photographer and scholar (b. 1898)

entities.title: Ernest Nash
entities.description: Ernest Nash was a student of Roman architecture and pioneer of archaeological photography. Nash was born as Ernst Nathan in Potsdam, Germany, but later changed his name to Nash when he was living in the United States between 1939 and 1952.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles E. Rosendahl, American admiral and pilot (b. 1892)

entities.title: Charles E. Rosendahl
entities.description: Charles Emery Rosendahl was a highly decorated Vice Admiral in the United States Navy, and an advocate of lighter-than-air flight.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gündüz Kılıç, Turkish football player and coach (b. 1918)

entities.title: Gündüz Kılıç
entities.description: "Baba" Gündüz Kılıç (1918–1980) was a Turkish football player and coach. He was Ali Kılıç's son and Altemur Kılıç's brother.

heading: Deaths
txt: Abe Burrows, American director, composer, and author (b. 1910)

entities.title: Abe Burrows
entities.description: Abe Burrows was an American humorist, author, and director for radio and the stage. He won a Tony Award and was selected for two Pulitzer Prizes, only one of which was awarded.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gunnar Myrdal, Swedish economist, sociologist, and politician, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1898)

entities.title: Gunnar Myrdal
entities.description: Karl Gunnar Myrdal was a Swedish economist and sociologist. In 1974, he received the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences with Friedrich Hayek for "their pioneering work in the theory of money and economic fluctuations and for their penetrating analysis of the interdependence of economic, social and institutional phenomena." He is best known in the United States for his study of race relation

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Economics
entities.description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences, officially the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel, is an economics prize administered by the Nobel Foundation. While it is not one of the Nobel Prizes, which were established by Alfred Nobel's will in 1895, it is commonly referred to as the Nobel Prize in Economics. The prize was established in 1968 by a donation fr

heading: Deaths
txt: Lawrence Welk, American accordion player and bandleader (b. 1903)

entities.title: Lawrence Welk
entities.description: Lawrence Welk was an American musician, accordionist, bandleader, and television impresario, who hosted the television program The Lawrence Welk Show from 1951 to 1982. His style came to be known to his large audience of radio, television, and live-performance fans as "champagne music".

heading: Deaths
txt: Toe Blake, Canadian ice hockey player and coach (b. 1912)

entities.title: Toe Blake
entities.description: Joseph Hector "Toe" Blake, was a Canadian ice hockey player and coach in the National Hockey League (NHL). He is best known for his three-decade association with the Montreal Canadiens, with whom he won the Stanley Cup eleven times as a player or coach. In 2017 Blake was named one of the '100 Greatest NHL Players' in history.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kevin Gilbert, American singer-songwriter and producer (b. 1966)

entities.title: Kevin Gilbert (musician)
entities.description: Kevin Matthew Gilbert was an American singer, songwriter, musician, composer, producer and collaborator. Gilbert was best known for his solo progressive rock projects, Toy Matinee and his contributions to Tuesday Night Music Club, the debut album by Sheryl Crow.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bruce Fairbairn, Canadian trumpet player and producer (b. 1949)

entities.title: Bruce Fairbairn
entities.description: Bruce Earl Fairbairn was a Canadian musician and international record producer from Vancouver, British Columbia. He was active as a producer from 1976 to 1999, and is considered one of the best of his era. His most successful productions are Slippery When Wet and New Jersey by Bon Jovi, Permanent Vacation, Pump, and Get a Grip by Aerosmith, The Razors Edge by AC/DC, and Balance by Van Halen, each

heading: Deaths
txt: Lembit Oll, Estonian chess Grandmaster (b. 1966)

heading: Deaths
txt: Donald Coggan, English archbishop (b. 1909)

entities.title: Donald Coggan
entities.description: Frederick Donald Coggan, Baron Coggan, was the 101st Archbishop of Canterbury from 1974 to 1980. As Archbishop of Canterbury, he "revived morale within the Church of England, opened a dialogue with Rome and supported women's ordination". He had previously been successively the Bishop of Bradford and the Archbishop of York.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacques-Louis Lions, French mathematician (b. 1928)

entities.title: Jacques-Louis Lions
entities.description: Jacques-Louis Lions was a French mathematician who made contributions to the theory of partial differential equations and to stochastic control, among other areas. He received the SIAM's John von Neumann Lecture prize in 1986 and numerous other distinctions. Lions is listed as an ISI highly cited researcher.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank G. Slaughter, American physician and author (b. 1908)

heading: Deaths
txt: László Kubala, Hungarian-Spanish footballer, coach, and manager (b. 1927)

entities.title: László Kubala
entities.description: László Kubala Stecz, also referred to as Ladislav Kubala or Ladislao Kubala (in Spanish), was a professional footballer. He played as a forward for Ferencváros, Slovan Bratislava, Barcelona, and Espanyol, among other clubs. Regarded as one of the best players in history, Kubala is considered a hero of FC Barcelona. A Hungarian national by birth, he also held Czechoslovak and Spanish citizenship, a

heading: Deaths
txt: Aşık Mahzuni Şerif, Turkish poet and composer (b. 1940)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jørgen Nash, Danish poet and painter (b. 1920)

entities.title: Jørgen Nash
entities.description: Jørgen Nash was a Danish artist, writer and central proponent of Situationism.

heading: Deaths

txt: Frank Gorshin, American actor (b. 1934)

entities.title: Frank Gorshin
entities.description: Frank John Gorshin Jr. was an American character actor, impressionist, and comedian. He was perhaps best known as an impressionist, with many guest appearances on The Ed Sullivan Show and Tonight Starring Steve Allen. His most famous acting role was as the Riddler on the live-action television series Batman, a performance for which he was nominated for an Emmy Award and catapulted the character to

heading: Deaths
txt: Cy Feuer, American director, producer, and composer (b. 1911)

entities.title: Cy Feuer
entities.description: Cy Feuer was an American theatre producer, director, composer, musician, and half of the celebrated producing duo Feuer and Martin. He won three competitive Antoinette Perry Awards for Excellence in Theatre, and a Lifetime Achievement Tony Award. He was also nominated for Academy Awards as the producer of Storm Over Bengal and Cabaret.

entities.title: Lloyd Alexander
entities.description: Lloyd Chudley Alexander was an American author of more than forty books, primarily fantasy novels for children and young adults. Over his seven-decade career, Alexander wrote 48 books, and his work has been translated into 20 languages. entities.title: Harmon Killebrew
entities.description: Harmon Clayton Killebrew Jr., nicknamed ’The Killer’ and ’Hammerin' Harmon’, was an American professional baseball first baseman, third baseman, and left fielder. He was a prolific power hitter who spent most of his 22-year career in Major League Baseball with the Minnesota Twins. At the time of his retirement Killebrew had the fourth-most home runs in major league history. He was second only to B

txt: Gideon Ezra, Israeli geographer and politician, Israeli Minister in the Prime Minister's Office (b. 1937)

entities.title: Gideon Ezra
entities.description: Gideon Ezra was an Israeli politician. He served as a member of the Knesset for Likud and Kadima between 1996 and 2012, and also held several ministerial portfolios.

entities.title: Minister in the Prime Minister's Office
entities.description: A Minister in the Prime Minister's Office is a minister and member of the Cabinet of Israel appointed by the Prime Minister of Israel to handle various issues on behalf of the Prime Minister.

heading: Deaths
txt: Philippe Gaumont, French cyclist (b. 1973)

entities.title: Philippe Gaumont
entities.description: Philippe Gaumont was a French professional road racing cyclist. He earned a bronze medal in the 1992 Summer Olympics, 100 km team time trial. In 1997 he won the Belgian classic Gent–Wevelgem and he was twice individual pursuit French national champion, in 2000 and 2002. In 2004, Gaumont quit professional cycling and later ran a café in Amiens.

entities.title: President of Argentina
entities.description: The President of Argentina, officially known as the President of the Argentine Nation, is both head of state and head of government of Argentina. Under the national Constitution, the President is also the chief executive of the federal government and Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces.

entities.title: Gerald Edelman
entities.description: Gerald Maurice Edelman was an American biologist who shared the 1972 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for work with Rodney Robert Porter on the immune system. Edelman's Nobel Prize-winning research concerned discovery of the structure of antibody molecules. entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

entities.title: The Leela Palaces, Hotels and Resorts
entities.description: The Leela Palaces, Hotels and Resorts, commonly known as The Leela, is an Indian luxury hotel chain, founded in 1986 by C. P. Krishnan Nair, and owned by Brookfield Asset Management. Currently, The Leela is a group of eight luxury palaces and hotels.

entities.title: Herman Wouk
entities.description: Herman Wouk was an American author best known for historical fiction such as The Caine Mutiny (1951) which won the Pulitzer Prize.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lucky Peterson, American blues singer, keyboardist and guitarist (b. 1964)

entities.title: Lucky Peterson
entities.description: Judge Kenneth Peterson, known professionally as Lucky Peterson, was an American musician who played contemporary blues, fusing soul, R&B, gospel and rock and roll. He played guitar and keyboards. Music journalist Tony Russell, in his book The Blues - From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray has said, "he may be the only blues musician to have had national television exposure in short pants."
